title: 108_s1215
content: The Act may be cited as the "Burmese Freedom and Democracy Act of 2003". Congress finds that the State Peace and Development Council (SPDC) in Burma has failed to transfer power to the National League for Democracy (NLD) despite their election victory in 1990. The SPDC has also refused to engage in meaningful dialogue with the NLD and ethnic minorities, becoming more confrontational according to a State Department report. Additionally, the SPDC violently attacked the NLD in response to their continued support throughout Burma. The SPDC in Burma has committed human rights violations, including attacking NLD supporters, using rape as a weapon, and conscripting child soldiers. They have also failed to cooperate with the United States in stopping drug trafficking and engage in business dealings with narcotics traffickers. The International Labor Organization (ILO) adopted a resolution in 2000 urging governments, employers, and workers organizations to avoid supporting forced labor in Burma by the SPDC. The SPDC has integrated the military into the economy. The SPDC in Burma has integrated the military into the economy, destroying free enterprise. Investments in Burmese companies fund the SPDC's repression. The US supports a ban on imports from Burma until human rights are respected. The NLD is officially recognized by the US. The US officially recognizes the NLD as the legitimate representative of the Burmese people based on the 1990 election. The US imposes a ban on trade that supports the military regime of Burma. The US imposes a ban on imports from Burma, including entities like the SPDC and known narcotics traffickers. The US bans imports from Burma, including entities like SPDC, UMEHI, MEC, USDA, or any successor entity. Conditions include ending human rights violations like rape. The SPDC has shown progress in implementing a democratic government by releasing political prisoners, allowing freedom of speech and press, freedom of association, peaceful exercise of religion, and reaching agreements with democratic forces. The SPDC has made progress in implementing a democratic government by releasing political prisoners and allowing freedoms of speech, press, association, and religion. Burma has not met its obligations under international counternarcotics agreements, including the arrest and extradition of individuals indicted in the US for narcotics trafficking. The SPDC in Burma has shown progress in democratic reforms by releasing political prisoners and allowing freedoms. However, the country has failed to meet international counternarcotics agreements, including extraditing individuals indicted in the US for drug trafficking. The proposed Act aims to combat narcotics trafficking and prevent illicit drug money from entering Burma's economy. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The President has the authority to waive import prohibitions from Burma to the US if certain conditions are met. The President may waive import prohibitions from Burma to the United States if it is in the vital national security interest of the US. The President can also waive any provision of the Act that violates international obligations of the US related to Burma under the World Trade Organization dispute settlement procedures. The Act directs the Secretary of the Treasury to freeze assets of the Burmese regime in the US held by financial institutions and individuals associated with the regime. Additionally, the Act addresses loans at international financial institutions. The Act directs the Secretary of the Treasury to oppose loans to Burma at international financial institutions until certain conditions are met. Additionally, it expands the visa ban. The Act expands the visa ban to deny visas and entry to the former and present leadership of the SPDC or the Union Solidarity Development Association. The Secretary of State will coordinate with the European Union to ensure consistency in visa bans. Names of banned individuals will be published on the Department of State's website. SEC. 7 of the Act condemns the SPDC regime and urges the Secretary of State to inform the international community about their poor record. It also calls for restricting financial resources to the SPDC and supporting Burma's democratic movement. The United States embassy in Rangoon is required to provide information to media not controlled by the regime. SEC. 8 focuses on supporting democracy activists in Burma. The President is authorized to use all available resources to assist Burmese democracy activists in promoting freedom, democracy, and human rights in Burma. The Secretary of State must provide reports on programs and resources supporting democracy activists within specified timeframes. The text chunk discusses the resources needed for the reconstruction of Burma post-SPDC, including democratic institutions, rule of law, freedom of the press, reintegration of military personnel, and health, education, and economic development. Additionally, a report on trade sanctions must be submitted 90 days before import restrictions expire. The report to congressional committees will cover conditions in Burma, including human rights violations, arrest of activists, forced labor, and dialogue status. It will also discuss measures by the US and other governments to promote human rights and democracy in Burma, and assess the impact of the Act on US policy objectives towards Burma. SEC. 9. DURATION OF SANCTIONS. The President can terminate provisions in the Act upon request from a democratically elected government in Burma if conditions are met. Import restrictions expire after 1 year unless renewed annually through a resolution by Congress. A renewal resolution is a joint resolution of Congress approving the renewal of import restrictions under the Burmese Freedom and Democracy Act of 2003. It can be introduced within 90 days before the restrictions expire. The provisions of the Trade Act of 1974 apply to a renewal resolution under the Burmese Freedom and Democracy Act of 2003 for expedited consideration. The Senate passed S. 1215 on June 11, 2003, to sanction the Burmese military junta, support democratic forces in Burma, and recognize the National League of Democracy as the legitimate representative of the Burmese people.
